[[food critic|Food critic]] | spouse = Mary Ann Quioc | parents = | children = }} '''Claudio Suarez Tayag''' (born 7 August 1956), more popularly known as '''Claude Tayag''', is a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] artist, restaurateur and [[food writer]]. He is best known for depicting scenes of impressionistic landscapes and scenes of Philippine folk festivals and religious imagery in his art. In recent years, he has written and been involved with Philippine gastronomy both as renowned chef and as food writer with his weekly column, ''Turo-Turo'' (Filipino for pinpoint) on ''[[The Philippine Star]]''. A scion of the Tayag family of [[Pampanga]], he is the son of author and journalist, Renato D. Tayag.{{Cite news|url=http://www.claudetayag.net/About%20Claude%20Tayag.htm|title=Claude Tayag: About Claude|date=2013|work=Bale Dutung|access-date=26 April 2018|language=en-US}} ==Biography and career== Tayag was born in [[Angeles City]] in the province of Pampanga on 7 August 1956 to Renato "Katoks" D. Tayag, a journalist for the ''[[Manila Times]]''; and Adoracion Suarez. Tayag married Mary Ann Quioc, a former flight attendant and trainer of [[Cathay Pacific]] and have a son Victor Nicolo. Tayag graduated with a bachelors degree in economics at the [[University of the Philippines Diliman]], but also undertook several courses in architecture at the same time.{{Citation |last=Pilar |first=Santiago Albano |title=CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art|place=Manila |publisher=Cultural Center of the Philippines |year=1994 |edition = First |isbn = 9789718546383}} From the circle of friends cultivated by his father, Tayag was surrounded by the noted personalities in the Philippine arts and letters including [[Emilio Aguilar Cruz]], [[Sofronio Mendoza]] (SYM), [[Romulo Galicano]], [[Adrian Cristobal Cruz]] and [[Ibarra dela Rosa]] who will later be collectively known as the Dimasalang Group. His encountering with Aguilar Cruz and others, spawned his oeuvre of painting in plein air leading to his first one-man exhibition at ABC Galleries in Manila in 1978 on his acrylic and watercolor landscapes. Consequently, in 1979, Tayag encountered the works of French-based Philippine painter [[Macario Vitalis]] while doing his travels on an eleven-month travel around Europe. Tayag and Vitalis became acquainted with each and whom he frequently visited in his residence in [[Plestin-les-Grèves]] in Brittany.{{Citation |last=Gelvezon-Tequi |first=Ofelia |title=Vintage Vitalis: Paintings and Drawings (1930–1965)|place=Makati City |publisher=Alliance Française de Manille |year=2011}} Subsequently, his paintings revolved on themes ranging from the local festivals in particular the [[Moriones festival|Moriones]] and the [[Ati-atihan]], Philippine folk religious imagery (better known as [[Santo (art)|santos]]), landscapes of the [[Cordillera]] region and a travelogue of sceneries in Europe and Japan from 1979 to 1980.{{Citation |last=Paras-Perez |first=Rod. |title=The Moriones Unmasked|place=Mandaluyong |publisher=Galerie Domenique|year=1981}} By 1990, Tayag delved towards woodwork and sculpture by forming sculptures delving in waves and abstractions by means of wood lamination. His sculptures and his wood furniture are mainly reminiscent of the works of [[Constantin Brâncuși]] and [[Alexander Calder]].{{Citation |last= |first= |title=Wood: Sculptures and Furniture in Wood by Claude R. Tayag|place=Mandaluyong City |publisher=[[SM Megamall]]|year=1997}} In 1989, after receiving a grant from the [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]] (CCP), Tayag made a large-scale black and white [[Ink wash painting|sumi]] painting known as ''Black Mountain'' which was later mounted in the lobby of the Little Theater of the CCP. The painting however was destroyed in a fire in the late 1990s. Tayag has actively participated in several one-man and group exhibitions in the Philippines, China, the United States, and Spain, where he exhibited with both Filipino, Southeast Asian and Spanish artists. In 2003, he held a three-man show with Ben Cabrera and Patis Tesoro in a museum in his hometown, Angeles City. Other Filipino artists who exhibited in group shows with him include [[Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi]], [[Phyllis Zaballero]], [[Soler Santos]], [[Abdulmari Imao]], and [[Sajid Imao]]. Tayag also participated in the 20th Asian International Art Exhibition at the [[Ayala Museum]] in 2005. In 2011, alongside with co-curator [[Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi]], Tayag curated the retrospective of the early works of French-based Philippine painter Vitalis at the Total Gallery space of the [[Alliance Française|Alliance Française de Manille]] in [[Makati City]] from 1 to 31 March 2011.{{Cite news|url=https://www.philstar.com/other-sections/starweek-magazine/2011/02/27/660934/rediscovering-macario-vitalis-road-less-taken|title=Rediscovering Macario Vitalis the road less taken |date=27 February 2011|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|access-date=26 April 2018|language=en-US}} === Public collections === Tayag's work is displayed in numerous public and private collections, including: * [[Bank of the Philippine Islands]] Collection (BPI) * [[Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas]] Collection (BSP) * [[Metropolitan Museum of Manila]] * Paulino and Hetty Que Collection * [[PLDT|Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company]] Collection (PLDT) ==Bibliography== * ''Imahen: A Folio of Philippine Folk Santos'' (1989) * ''Food Tour: A Culinary Journal'' (2006) * ''Kulinarya: A Guidebook to Philippine Cuisine'' (2008; as co-author) * ''Linamnam: Eating One's Way Around the Philippines'' (2014) ==References== {{portal|Pampanga}} {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.claudetayag.net/ Official Website of Claude Tayag] {{Filipino painters}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tayag, Claude}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Artists from Pampanga]] [[Category:People from Angeles, Philippines]] [[Category:Filipino painters]] [[Category:Filipino sculptors]] [[Category:20th-century Filipino painters]] [[Category:20th-century Filipino sculptors]] [[Category:21st-century Filipino sculptors]] [[Category:Kapampangan people]] [[Category:Living people]]

page.title: Commandants of the U.S. Air Force Test Pilot School

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Lists of people by institutional affiliation to [[:Category:Lists of people by organization]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 13]].
revision.text:
[[File:USAF TPS PAM 36-7 22 June 2007.png|right|thumb|300px|USAF Test Pilot School, Edwards AFB, California]] The commanding officer of the [[U.S. Air Force Test Pilot School]] (USAF TPS) is known as its '''Commandant'''. The commandant manages the school which is a military unit that operates in a distinctly academic atmosphere.{{cite book |title = USAF TPS Graduate Course Catalog |page = 14}} The position is usually held by a [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] selected by the [[Air Force Materiel Command]] (AFMC) commander although this authority may be delegated to the commander of the [[Air Force Flight Test Center]] (AFFTC).{{cite book |title = Air Force Instruction 99-107, Test Pilot School |page = 7}} The commandant oversees all flying training, academic instruction, budgeting, and curriculum administration at the school.{{cite book |title = Air Force Instruction 99-107, Test Pilot School |page = 8}} The commandant also chairs a board of officers that selects the school's students. The selection board consists of flight test squadron commanders with a majority of the board members being TPS graduates.{{cite book |title = Air Force Instruction 99-107, Test Pilot School |page = 11}} Every three years, the commandant conducts a review of the school's curriculum with participation from flight test squadrons, the [[United States Naval Test Pilot School|U.S. Naval TPS]], and operational squadrons. The school's mission is to produce experimental [[test pilot]]s, flight [[Test Engineer|test engineer]]s, and flight test [[Flight officer|navigators]] to lead and conduct test and evaluation of aerospace weapon systems.{{cite book | title = USAF TPS Graduate Course Catalog | page = 9}} The school was established on September 9, 1944 as the Flight Test Training Unit at [[Wright-Patterson Air Force Base]] (AFB) in [[Dayton, Ohio]].{{cite web | title = U.S. Air Force Test Pilot School History | url = http://www.edwards.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=6586 | accessdate =2017-02-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303231218/http://www.edwards.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=6586 |archivedate=2016-03-03 | publisher=United States Air Force}} To take advantage of the uncongested skies and superb flying weather, the school was moved on February 4, 1951 to its present location at [[Edwards Air Force Base]] in the [[Mojave Desert]] of [[Southern California]]. Edwards AFB is the home of the Air Force Flight Test Center and has been an integral part of flight testing for over fifty years.{{cite web |title = Edwards Air Force Base |url = http://www.edwards.af.mil/ |publisher = United States Air Force |accessdate = 2008-08-05}} Between 1962 and 1972, the Test Pilot School expanded its role to include astronaut training for military test pilots.{{cite book | title = USAF Test Pilot School 50 Years and Beyond | page = 233}} Thirty-seven TPS graduates of this era were selected for the U.S. space program, and twenty-six went on to earn astronaut's wings by flying in the [[North American X-15|X-15]], [[Project Gemini|Gemini]], [[Apollo program|Apollo]], and [[Space Shuttle program|Space Shuttle]] programs.{{cite book | first = J | last = Young | title = Forging Aerospace Power for America | pages = 3–4}} Although the school no longer trains astronauts, many TPS graduates since 1972 have been selected by the [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA) for duties in space. The school encourages applications from civilians, personnel from other U.S. military services, and individuals from foreign countries.{{cite book |title = USAF TPS Graduate Course Catalog |page = 19}} An exchange program allows selected students to attend other test pilot schools including the [[United States Naval Test Pilot School]], the United Kingdom's [[Empire Test Pilots' School]] (ETPS), and France's [[École du personnel navigant d'essais et de réception]] (EPNER).{{cite book | title = USAF TPS Graduate Course Catalog |page = 18}} == Commandants == The following list provides a complete list of commandants of the U.S. Air Force Test Pilot School. The table contains their name, rank, dates as commandant, the TPS class from which they graduated (if applicable), and notable events that occurred during their tenure at the school. === Key === {| class="wikitable" border="1" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" style="width:78%;" |- ! rowspan="1"|'''Rank''' | align="center" | [[Military rank]] | The rank shown is at the time the individual served as commandant. |- ! rowspan="2" |'''Class''' | align="center" | Year/Letter | The year and order in which a class started. For example, 07A was the first of two classes to start in 2007.{{cite book | title = USAF TPS Graduate Course Catalog |page = 8}} |- | align="center" | Roman Numeral | Four Aerospace Research Pilot School (ARPS) classes designated I, II, III, and IV, that prepared students for manned spaceflight operations. These classes were dropped when the USAF lost its manned spaceflight mission.{{cite book | title = USAF Test Pilot School 50 Years and Beyond |page = 50}} |- ! rowspan="1"|'''Events''' | align="center" | "introduced" | Indicates an aircraft type was first made available for use by TPS students. This date is usually much later than the aircraft entered USAF service. |- |} ===List of Commandants=== [[File:Aldrin.jpg|right|thumb|150px| [[Buzz Aldrin]]]] [[File:Colonel Steve Cameron 2001.jpg |right|thumb|150px| Steve Cameron]] [[File:USAF Colonel Ken Chilstrom 1961.jpg|right|thumb|150px| [[Kenneth O. Chilstrom|Ken Chilstrom]]]] [[File:USAF-EP-Deatrick-by-F-104-1968.png|right|thumb|150px| [[Eugene Peyton Deatrick|Gene Deatrick]]]] [[File:James H. Doolittle III TPS Commandant 1994-96.jpg|right|thumb|150px| Jim Doolittle, III]] [[File:Guy Gardner.jpg|right|thumb|150px| [[Guy Gardner (astronaut)|Guy Gardner]]]] [[File:Colonel Joe Guthrie Jr USAF.jpg|thumb|right|150px| Joe Guthrie]] [[File:Col. Ralph C. Hoewing.png |right|thumb|150px| Ralph Hoewing]] [[File:130405-F-ZZ999-001.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Lars Hoffman]] [[File:George-Kailiwali-Sept-2008.jpg|right|thumb|150px| George Ka'iliwai III]] [[File:MGen Michael Kostelnik 2001.jpg|right|thumb|150px| Michael Kostelnik]] [[File:Col Mike Luallen 2008.JPG|right|thumb|150px| Mike Luallen]] [[File:Colonel Charles Webb USAF October 22. 2014. 141020-F-IW159-006 - cropped.jpg|right|thumb|150px| Charles Webb]] [[File:Charles Yeager photo portrait head on shoulders left side.jpg|right|thumb|150px| [[Chuck Yeager]]]] [[File:Col Noel Zamot USAF TPS Retires 20120619 120613-F-CX978-076.jpg|right|thumb|150px| Noel Zamot]] {{color box|#e3d9ff| * }} Individual was killed in an aviation-related accident.

#REDIRECT [[Viktor_Orbán#Controversy_and_criticisms]] [[Category:Criticism of individuals]]

'''Dirty Dishes''' is a New York City-based American rock band founded by songwriter/singer/guitarist Jenny Tuite. Dirty Dishes' style is described as heavy-laden hooks blasting headfirst into speaker-shredding fuzz.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/01/13/dirty-dishes-guilty|title=Grunge-poppers Dirty Dishes get dreamy on 'Guilty' -- exclusive|work=Entertainment Weekly's EW.com}}</ref> Sonically the band has been compared to Smashing Pumpkins, My Bloody Valentine, Radiohead, and Sonic Youth.
== History == On January 27, 2015, Dirty Dishes released their debut album “Guilty” on Exploding in Sound Records. Recording for the album was split between Los Angeles, CA and Chelsea, MA.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dirtydishes.bandcamp.com/|title=Dirty Dishes|date=27 January 2015|work=Dirty Dishes}}</ref> The album was engineered by Chris Thompson and recorded in Thompson’s garage.<ref name="bdcwire.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.bdcwire.com/list/from-los-angeles-with-love-catching-up-with-former-locals-dirty-dishes/|title=From Los Angeles With Love: Catching Up With Dirty Dishes - BDCwire|work=bdcwire.com}}</ref> The album was well-received and described as "enduring a waking dream — it’s both a harrowing and totally beautiful experience” by Stereogum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stereogum.com/1727848/stream-dirty-dishes-guilty/mp3s/|title=Stream Dirty Dishes Guilty (Stereogum Premiere)|work=Stereogum}}</ref> "Dirty Dishes’ composition is refreshing and intense. Guilty is clearly the result of Tuite's significant growth as a songwriter, and is the kind of record that a band can build a following on."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://funeralsounds.com/reviews/dirty-dishes-guilty-los-angeles-california/|title=Dirty Dishes - Guilty (Los Angeles, California) - Funeral Sounds|work=Funeral Sounds}}</ref> The album cover is a photo of a school that expelled Tuite.
On January 28, 2015 the band released the music video for “Thank You Come Again” The video premiered on The A.V Club and was directed by Pat Bishop of the comedy group Women. The video was inspired by Tuite's experience working at grocery store in Silverlake.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/watch-dirty-dishes-wreak-havoc-doughnut-shop-214420|title=Watch Dirty Dishes wreak havoc on a doughnut shop|work=avclub.com}}</ref>
On January 29, 2016 the band released the music video for "Guilty." The video premiered on Independent Music News, and was directed by [[The Current Sea]], the creative team of [[Sarah Zucker]] and [[Brian Griffith (director)|Brian Griffith]]. The video features an alien figurine taking a miniature fern out for a walk, eventually liberating the fern on a mountain overlooking Los Angeles, with psychedelic analog visuals. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://independentmusicnews.com/video-premiere-dirty-dishes-guilty/|title=Video Premiere / Dirty Dishes / Guilty|work=independentmusicnews.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.stereogum.com/1856190/dirty-dishes-guilty-video/video/|title=Dirty Dishes – "Guilty" Video|work=stereogum.com}}</ref>
On February 8th, 2016 the band released their single "All of Me." The track premiered on Noisey, along with a long string of national U.S. tour dates.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://noisey.vice.com/blog/dirty-dishes-all-of-me|title=Premiere: Dirty Dishes"All of Me"|work=noisey.com}}</ref>
== Discography == === Studio Albums ===
* ''Guilty'' (2015)

* ''The Most Tarnished Birds'' (2012) * ''Dirty Dishes'' (2010)
=== Singles === * ''All of Me'' (2016)

'''Eleanor Ambrose''' (1718–1816) was a celebrated beauty and Catholic heiress. Her father, Michael, was well-educated but disbarred from several professions by his religion. He became a [[brewer]] and made his fortune. He resided at Mount Ambrose, [[Swords, County Dublin]].
Eleanor was described as "beautiful, witty, intellectual and a fevent [[patriotism|patriot]]" who "managed to penetrate Dublin society, despite the fact that she was a Catholic. Indeed, she became a darling of the Viceregal Court, and during the Viceroyalty of [[Philip Stanhope, 4th Earl of Chesterfield|Lord Chesterfield]], she and her sister Clara were the prominent socialites of the Castle set. Chesterfield was attracted to her, and she soon accompanied him to all official ceremonies. Influenced by her opinions, Chesterfield is reported to have told [[George II of Great Britain|George II]] that ''poverty not Popery was to be feared in Ireland'', he had found ''only one dangerous papist, the brightness of whose eyes and charms, and whose conversation were indeed dangerous'', and her name was Eleanor Ambrose".<ref>http://www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/history-heritage/big-houses-of-ireland/kenure-house/roger-palmer/</ref>
However, Eleanor ensured the relationship stayed [[platonic love|platonic]].
{{quote|"At one of the Castle balls, given on the anniversary of the battle of the Boyne, she appeared with an orange lily in her breast, upon which Chesterfield improvised the following lines:
:"''Say, lovely [[Tory (British political party)|tory]], where's the jest'' :''Of wearing orange on thy breast,'' :''When that same breast uncovered shows'' :''The whiteness of the rebel rose?''"<ref name=libraryireland>http://www.libraryireland.com/biography/MissAmbrose.php</ref>}}
In 1752 she married Roger Palmer of Castle Lackin, [[County Mayo]] (created [[baronet]] 1777) and had issue. She died at her house on [[Henry Street, Dublin]], in 1816, "retaining to the last a vehement hatred of the wrongs under which her Catholic fellow-countrymen laboured."<ref name=libraryireland/>
A song written about her story by Aido Lawlor - from Rush North Co Dublin - was recorded by the singer Aoife Scott on her 2016 album Carry the Day.
==See also== * [[Palmer Baronets]] * [[Mary Barber (poet)|Mary Barber]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=September 2018}} {{update|date=February 2018}} }}
{{expand language|topic=|langcode=fr|otherarticle=Affaire Estelle Mouzin|date=February 2018}}
The '''Estelle Mouzin affair''' is a French criminal case which began on 9 January 2003 with the disappearance of Estelle Mouzin in the city of [[Guermantes]] in [[France]]. Estelle Mouzin was a nine-year-old girl who was returning from school when she disappeared.
==Disappearance== On Thursday 9 January 2003, Estelle Mouzin, a nine-year-old girl, disappeared on the way back from school in Guermantes. She was seen for the last time in front of a bakery, while she was coming back to her mother's home, Suzanne Mouzin, who was in the process of divorce with the girl's father, Eric Mouzin. Her mother reported the fact she was missing to the local police station shortly after 7 P.M.<ref>[[France Info]], 8 January 2013, [http://www.franceinfo.fr/politique/le-zoom-du-matin/la-disparition-d-estelle-mouzin-10-ans-apres-854393-2013-01-08 La disparition d'Estelle Mouzin, 10 ans après]</ref> Her disappearance had a huge media coverage all over the country.
==Investigations==
===First suspect=== The first person to be suspected was serial killer [[Michel Fourniret]], who was arrested in June 2003 in [[Belgium]]. However, after consideration, the police discounted Fourniret because he had an alibi: a phonecall was made from his home at the time of Estelle Mouzin's disappearance.<ref>[[Le Figaro]], 6 January 2007, [http://www.lefigaro.fr/france/20070106.WWW000000058_pas_de_lien_entre_fourniret_et_la_disparition_d_estelle_.html Pas de lien entre Fourniret et la disparition d'Estelle] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929120442/http://www.lefigaro.fr/france/20070106.WWW000000058_pas_de_lien_entre_fourniret_et_la_disparition_d_estelle_.html |date=2007-09-29 }}</ref>
Two weeks before Estelle's disappearance, a girl of the same age was almost kidnapped by a man in a white van, from which she was able to make a facial composite. When Fourniret was suspected, investigators showed his photo to the girl, and he says it wasn't him who tried to kidnap her. While taking the police to a place he buried one of his victims, Fourniret described the clothes his victim was wearing, and it was very close to those Estelle wore the day she disappeared.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
Despite his alibi and the fact Fourniret denied any involvement in this case, the fact it could be Fourniret was taken into consideration when the police found a television recording and photos of the girl at the suspect's home and on his computer.<ref>[[Le Figaro]], 17 November 2006, [http://www.lefigaro.fr/france/20061117.WWW000000293_disparition_destelle_mouzin_fourniret_de_nouveau_dans_la_ligne_de_mire.html Disparition d’Estelle Mouzin : l'hypothèse Fourniret relancée] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070818181939/http://www.lefigaro.fr/france/20061117.WWW000000293_disparition_destelle_mouzin_fourniret_de_nouveau_dans_la_ligne_de_mire.html |date=2007-08-18 }}</ref><ref>[[Le Monde]], 17 November 2006, [http://www.lemonde.fr/web/article/0,1-0%402-3224,36-835867%4051-916808,0.html Disparition d'Estelle Mouzin : la piste Fourniret ressurgit]</ref><ref>[[RTL (France)|RTL]], 20 November 2006, [http://www.rtl.fr/info/article.asp?dicid=492475 Affaire Estelle Mouzin, Michel Fourniret serait-il en cause ?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927020045/http://www.rtl.fr/info/article.asp?dicid=492475 |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref> The hypothesis of the implication of Fourniret is abandoned in 2007, for lack of sufficient proofs, and the fact he has an alibi.
The inquiry, led by the commissioner Jean-Marc Bloch, employed unprecedented means in French history; more than 130 persons were interrogated by the police and all the houses of the city were seized.<ref>[[France 2]] (archived by the [[Institut national de l'audiovisuel|Ina]]), 16 June 2005, [http://www.ina.fr/video/2857019001019/audition-affaire-estelle-mouzin-video.html Audition affaire Estelle Mouzin]</ref>
Each year, a march is organised in memory of Estelle Mouzin.<ref>[[France 2]] (archived by the [[Institut national de l'audiovisuel|Ina]]), 6 January 2007, [http://www.ina.fr/video/3254884001008/le-quatrieme-anniversaire-de-la-disparition-d-estelle-mouzin-video.html Le quatrième anniversaire de la disparition d'Estelle Mouzin]</ref>
===2008 investigations===
[[File:Estelle_Mouzin_Brie.JPG|thumb|[[Brie-Comte-Robert]], 1st février 2008, a lot of medias covered the investigation.]]Several arrests took place on Thursday 31 January 2008 in the cities of [[Brie-Comte-Robert]] and [[Lognes]] ([[Seine-et-Marne]]). A search was conducted at the Royal Wok restaurant in Brie-Comte-Robert, where it was suspected human remains were used.<ref>20 minutes, 31 January 2008, [http://www.20minutes.fr/france/209968-20080131-disparition-estelle-mouzin-interpellations-restaurant-seine-et-marne Disparition d'Estelle Mouzin: interpellations dans un restaurant en Seine-et-Marne]</ref> On February 1, this track proved to be unsuccessful; only the remains of an animal were found in the place.
===2009 onward investigations=== {{Empty section|date=April 2018}}

{{distinguish|Colombians in France}} {{Infobox ethnic group| |group = Franco-Columbians |native_name = {{small|''Franco-Colombiens''}} |flag = [[File:Flag of the Franco-Colombiens.svg|200px|border]]
Franco-Columbian flag |image = [[Image:Gilbert Brule.jpg|63px]][[Image:Modeste Demers.jpg|79px]][[Image:HenriGustaveJolydeLotbiniere23.jpg|80px]][[Image:Grimes.jpg|115px]][[Image:Denise Savoie.jpg|80px]] |caption= [[Gilbert Brulé]]{{·}}[[Modeste Demers]]{{·}}[[Henri-Gustave Joly de Lotbinière]]
[[Grimes (musician)|Grimes]]{{·}}[[Denise Savoie]] |population = 64,325{{cite web |title=Census 2016, focus on geography series - British Columbia - Official language minority community |url=https://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2016/as-sa/fogs-spg/Facts-PR-Eng.cfm?TOPIC=5&LANG=Eng&GK=PR&GC=59 |accessdate=17 October 2018}} |popplace = [[British Columbia]] |langs = [[Canadian French]] |rels = predominantly [[Christianity|Christian]] ([[Roman Catholicism]], other denominations) |related = [[Franco-Manitoban]]s{{·}} [[Franco-Ontarian]]s{{·}} [[Fransaskois]]{{·}} [[French Canadians]]{{·}} [[French-speaking Quebecer|Québécois]]{{·}} [[Acadians]]{{·}} [[Cajuns]]{{·}} [[French Americans]]{{·}} [[Métis people (Canada)|Metis]]{{·}} [[French people|French]] }} '''Franco-Columbians''' ({{lang-fr|Franco-Colombiens}}) are [[French Canadians]] or French-speaking [[Canadians]] ([[Francophones]]) living in the [[Provinces and territories of Canada|Canadian province]] of [[British Columbia]]. British Columbia is, geographically, the farthest-removed province from Canada's historic [[francophone]] population, thus it is not surprising to find that francophone British Columbians are few in number. The 2001 census placed the number of British Columbians with [[French language|French]] as a mother tongue at 57,280, 1.3% of BC's population, ranking seventh after [[English language|English]] (3,062,430), 'other [[Chinese language|Chinese]]' (357,865), [[Yue Chinese|Cantonese]] (133,245), [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] (94,055), [[German language|German]] (73,625), and [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] (66,120). A good number of these listed francophones would be European and African immigrants or migrants from eastern Canada making the Franco-Columbian community a diverse one encompassing many places of origin and differing roots in the province. The popularity of French immersion education programmes have also meant that the population of second-language French speakers outnumbers the francophone population. ==Maillardville== {{main|Maillardville}} While Francophones have a significant history in the province due to the founders of the [[Hudson's Bay Company|Hudson's Bay]] and [[North West Company|North West companies]], who were mostly [[Metis (Canada)|Metis]], and during the gold rushes of the 1860s, when many from [[France]] and [[Belgium]] became notable in business and society, organized migration from Quebec did not happen until the early 19th century, when the owners of [[Fraser Mills]] imported mill workers from that province, forming the community of [[Maillardville]], a neighbourhood of [[Coquitlam]] in suburban [[Vancouver]]. In 1909 mill workers were brought from [[Quebec]] to Maillardville[http://www.maillardville.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12&Itemid=31 Societe francophone de Maillardville - À propos de nous / About us] and their descendants constitute a small and proud community.{{Cite web |url=http://www.library.coquitlam.bc.ca/Online+Services/Historical+Photographs/default.htm |title=Historical Photographs |access-date=2008-02-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080215152259/http://www.library.coquitlam.bc.ca/Online+Services/Historical+Photographs/default.htm |archive-date=2008-02-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Today Maillardville describes itself as "a community with a francophone heart" and is home to a number of francophone community organizations,[http://www.maillardville.com/ Societe francophone de Maillardville - Bienvenue/Welcome] schools, churches,[http://www.notredamedefatima.org/ Notre Dame de Fatima - Our Lady of Fatima Catholic Church][http://www.olol-coq.com/ Our Lady of Lourdes Notre Dame de Lourdes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725015327/http://www.olol-coq.com/ |date=2008-07-25 }} a retirement home,[http://www.foyermaillard.com/index2.htm Foyer Maillard Welcomes You!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080321134434/http://foyermaillard.com/index2.htm |date=2008-03-21 }} the annual ''[[Festival du Bois]]'',[http://www.festivaldubois.ca/ Festival du Bois - Société francophone de Maillardville] and an organization of francophone [[Scouting and Guiding in British Columbia|scouts and guides]].http://www.scoutsfranco.com/#/historiquepage2/4521359167 Community organizations place the francophone population of the Coquitlam area at 13,000. ==Francophone service and community centres elsewhere in the province== Francophone community centres and resources also exist in Vancouver,{{cite web |url=http://www.lamaison.bc.ca/MaisonHistory.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-02-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121082703/http://www.lamaison.bc.ca/MaisonHistory.htm |archivedate=2007-11-21 |df= }}[https://web.archive.org/web/20070704140815/http://www.lbv.ca/fr/index.html Bienvenue] [[Prince George, British Columbia|Prince George]],{{cite web |url=http://www.studio2880.com/members/cultural_members.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-02-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071127121435/http://www.studio2880.com/members/cultural_members.htm |archivedate=2007-11-27 |df= }} [[Nelson, British Columbia|Nelson]],AFKO http://www.afko.ca/[[Kelowna]],[http://kelowna.cioc.ca/details.asp?RSN=651 Centre francophone de services à l'emploi de l'Okanagan, Okanagan French Cultural Centre / Employment Services] [[Penticton]],[http://kelowna.cioc.ca/details.asp?RSN=651 Centre francophone de services à l'emploi de l'Okanagan, Okanagan French Cultural Centre / Employment Services] [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]],[http://www.francocentre.com/ La Société francophone de Victoria] [[Nanaimo]][http://www.francophonenanaimo.org/ L'Association des francophones de Nanaimo] and [[Kamloops]].[http://www.francokamloops.org/ Association francophone de Kamloops - Accueil] The Fédération des Francophones de la C.-B. (www.ffcb.ca) is the giant umbrella organization assembling all other francophone associations in BC - see https://web.archive.org/web/20140810040706/http://www.ffcb.ca/nos-membres/liste-des-membres/ ==Education== The province is served by a francophone school board ([[Le Conseil scolaire francophone de la Colombie-Britannique]]) which operates 40 schools offering education from kindergarten through grade 12 in the [[Lower Mainland]], [[Sunshine Coast, British Columbia|Sunshine Coast]], [[Vancouver Island]], [[Okanagan Valley|Okanagan]], [[Kootenays]], Prince George, [[Fraser Valley]], and other parts of the province.[http://www.csf.bc.ca/doc_pdf/accueil/2007_CSF_liste_ecoles.pdf liste_ecoles_08.cdr] A large and vibrant French immersion programme, although intended for anglophones, also includes some francophone students. The province hosts an active chapter of Canadian Parents for French (BC-Yukon Branch).[http://www.cpf.bc.ca/bc_html/Other/FramePages/f_index.shtml Canadian Parents for French - British Columbia & Yukon Branch] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219235701/http://www.cpf.bc.ca/bc_html/Other/FramePages/f_index.shtml |date=2007-12-19 }} Although French courses, and training for French immersion teaching are offered at the province's universities, there is no bilingual or French-language university in the province. [[Simon Fraser University]], however, offers five degree programmes that can be completed entirely in French.[http://www.cpf.bc.ca/site/dox/cpfutures2007.pdf pdf tab.indd]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[Educacentre College]] is the province's only French-language college with campuses in [[Vancouver]], [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]] and [[Prince George, British Columbia|Prince George]] as well as distance education options. ==Media== Vancouver-based television station [[CBUFT-DT]] broadcasts throughout the province via relay transmitters, as do French-language radio stations [[CBUF-FM]] ([[Première Chaîne]]) and, to a lesser extent, [[CBUX-FM]] ([[Espace musique]]).[http://www.cbc.radio-canada.ca/installations/stations/cb.shtml CBC/Radio-Canada - Stations de bases et affiliées - Colombie-Britannique] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080304031235/http://cbc.radio-canada.ca/installations/stations/cb.shtml |date=2008-03-04 }} Other French-language media such as CBC's ''[[Ici RDI]]'', [[TV5 Québec Canada|TV5]] and ''[[MusiquePlus]]'' are also available but not locally based. [[TVA (Canada)|TVA's]] [[owned-and-operated station]] in [[Montreal]] ([[CFTM-DT]]) is also available on basic cable. Between 1968 and 1998, the province had a newspaper called ''Le Soleil de la Colombie-Britannique''.[http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/07/7654.htm Le Soleil de la Colombie-Britannique ne paraît plus - Radio-Canada nouvelles] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605070348/http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/07/7654.htm |date=2011-06-05 }} A digitized version of the complete run of the newspaper is available online.http://newspapers.lib.sfu.ca/soleildecolombie-collection There is now a newspaper published out of [[Vancouver]] called ''L'Express du Pacifique''.[http://journaux.apf.ca/expresspacifique/ ''L'Express du Pacifique''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501225507/http://journaux.apf.ca/expresspacifique/ |date=2008-05-01 }} The Société radio communautaire Victoria, started in 1999 as an offshoot of the Société francophone de Victoria, was incorporated in 2004 and started on-air FM radio programming on 7 November 2007 non-stop as CILS-FM at 107.9 MHz and 250 watts - see www.cilsfm.ca ==Culture== In addition to Coquitlam's annual [[Festival du Bois]],[http://www.festivaldubois.ca/ Festival du Bois - Société Maillardville-Uni] Canadian Parents for French host an annual French Celebration Week, Francapalooza, a French film festival and French-language youth camps targeting both Francophone and French immersion students.[http://www.cpf.bc.ca/site/modules/news/index.php?storytopic=82 Canadian Parents for French - CPF] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20070617081039/http://www.cpf.bc.ca/site/modules/news/index.php?storytopic=82 |date=2007-06-17 }} ''L'Association des Ecrivains de la Colombie Britannique'' publishes a monthly youth magazine called ''La Moustique''. A French-language theatre group called ''Théâtre la Seizième'' is also active in the province[http://www.seizieme.ca/ Théâtre la Seizième] as well as the dance troupes ''Danseurs du Pacifique''http://canadiancharities.landoffree.com/charity/Societe_Des_Danseurs_Du_Pacifique and ''Les Cornouillers'',http://www.ccafcb.com/index.php/en/component/sobi2/?sobi2Task=sobi2Details&catid=11&sobi2Id=22 and the annual BC Francophone Games. The ''Conseil Culturel et Artistique de la Colombie Britannique'' serves as a community organization in the area of arts and culture.[http://www.ccafcb.com/ Conseil Culturel et Artistique de la Colombie-Britannique (CCAFCB)] The Association Historique Francophone de Victoria (https://sites.google.com/site/associationhistoriquevictoria/), started in 1985 as an offshoot of the Société francophone de Victoria, has published a book called "Présence francophone à Victoria (1843 - 1987)" - see http://www.espacesfrancophones.uwaterloo.ca/images/documents/PresenceFrancophoneAVictoriaC.pdf ==Notable Franco-Columbians== * [[Sébastien Bordeleau]], [[Ice_hockey|hockey]] player (born 1975) * [[Modeste Demers]], Canadian missionary and first Bishop of Vancouver Island (1809-1871) * [[David Emerson]], politician and former minister (born 1945) * [[Grimes_(musician)|Grimes]], musician (born 1988) * [[Henri-Gustave Joly de Lotbinière]], premier of Québec and later [[Lieutenant Governor of British Columbia]] (1829-1908) * {{Redirect|Frederick Middleton|the English footballer|Fred Middleton}} {{for|the cricketer|Frederick Middleton (cricketer)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = General | name = Sir Frederick Dobson Middleton | honorific_suffix = KCMG, CB |birth_date=4 November 1825 |death_date={{death-date and age|25 January 1898|4 November 1825}} |image=FrederickMiddleton.jpg |caption=Sir Frederick Middleton |nickname= |birth_place= [[Belfast]], [[Ireland]] |death_place= [[London]], [[England]] |allegiance= United Kingdom
Canada |branch= [[British Army]]
[[Canadian Militia]] |serviceyears=1845–1890 |rank=[[General (United Kingdom)|General]] |unit= |commands=[[Royal Military College, Sandhurst]]
[[General Officer Commanding the Canadian Militia]] |battles=[[New Zealand land wars|New Zealand Wars]]
[[Indian Rebellion of 1857|Indian Mutiny]]
[[North-West Rebellion]] |awards=[[Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]]
[[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] |relations= |laterwork= }} [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] '''Sir Frederick Dobson Middleton''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|KCMG|CB}} (4 November 1825 – 25 January 1898) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] general noted for his service throughout the [[British Empire|Empire]] and particularly in the [[North-West Rebellion]]. ==Military career== Educated at [[Maidstone Grammar School]] and the [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst]], Middleton was [[Commissioned Officer|commissioned]] into the [[58th Regiment of Foot]] in 1842.{{cite DCB |title=Middleton, Frederick Dodson |first=Desmond |last=Morton |volume=12 |url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/middleton_frederick_dobson_12E.html}} He served in the [[New Zealand land wars|New Zealand Wars]] and in 1845, he was [[mentioned in dispatches]] for his part in the capture of the stronghold of [[Māori people|Māori]] chief [[Te Ruki Kawiti]]. In 1848 he transferred to the [[96th Regiment of Foot]] in [[British Raj|India]] and took part in the suppression of the [[Indian Rebellion of 1857|Indian Mutiny]] in which campaign he was recommended for, but not actually awarded, the [[Victoria Cross]]. He went on to be [[List of Governors and Commandants of Sandhurst|Commandant of the Royal Military College, Sandhurst]], in 1879. He was appointed [[Commander of the Canadian Army|General Officer Commanding the Militia of Canada]] in 1884. In 1885 a group of [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] launched the [[North-West Rebellion]], and Middleton was named commander of the main force sent to put it down. After a defeat at the [[Battle of Fish Creek]], his force arrived at [[Batoche, Saskatchewan]] and was victorious in the [[Battle of Batoche]]. Middleton left Ottawa and arrived in Winnipeg to evaluate Military District 10 which covered the Prairies as the officer in charge of District 10 had just been dismissed on the account of his alcoholism, the same day as the [[Battle of Duck Lake]], where the [[North-West Mounted Police]] were defeated by the ''Métis''.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=101}} Through Middleton was elderly and cautious, his response to the news of Duck Lake was swift and on the same day, he departed Winnipeg on a train bound for Qu'Apelle with a company of Manitoba militia.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=101}} The major difficulty for Middleton was mobilizing the militia who had to travel from Ontario and Quebec on the partially completed Canadian Pacific Railway, requiring that the militiamen march through the snows and rocks of northern Ontario to reach Winnipeg.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=102}} The Canadian historian Desmond Morton described Middleton as an experienced soldier who "...mixed common sense and pomposity in equal measure", whose plan was to take Batoche, the capital of the Métis ''exovedate'' (council), which he predicated would end the rebellion.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=102}} As the rebellion had shaken international confidence in the credit-worthiness of Canada, Middleton was under immense pressure from the Prime Minister, Sir John A. Macdonald, to end the rebellion as soon as possible.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=102}} The militiamen arriving in Winnipeg were mostly untrained, and Middleton had to train them as they marched to Saskatchewan.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=102}} On 6 April 1885, Middleton set off on a march to Batoche.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=102}} On 23 April 1885, the ''Métis'' and Cree Indians under [[Gabriel Dumont (Métis leader)|Gabriel Dumont]] ambushed the Canadians at Fish Creek.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|pages=102-103}} Despite Middeton's orders, Colonel [[William Dillon Otter]] after reaching Battleford, set out to do battle with the Cree, and was defeated by Chief [[Poundmaker]] at the [[Battle of Cut Knife Hill]]; only the latter's unwillingness to have his warriors take advantage of the rout saved the Canadians from being annihilated.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=104}} Poundmaker was a reluctant rebel against Canada, and did not want the Canadian forces annihilated, believing this would save his people from reprisals.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=104}} Middleton planned to advance on Batchoe with river streamers owned by the Hudson's Bay Company bringing up supplies along the South Saskatchewan river, and as streamers were not available at first, Middleton chose to wait.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=103}} Despite their own panic at Fish Creek, many of the militiamen came to curse "Old Fred" as too timid, but Middleton had sound reasons for not wishing to advance without a means of resupply.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=104}} Middleton knew that the ''Métis'' and the Cree were expert horsemen and believed they would ambush any supply wagons, which is why he preferred to bring up supplies and reinforcements via the river.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=103}} On 5 May 1885, the streamer ''Northcote'' was ready and Middleton set off for Batoche.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=104}} On 9 May 1885, the ''Northcote'' was stopped by a cable that Dumont had laid across the river outside of Batoche, and its American captain turned back when the boat came under fire.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=104}} The ''Northcote'' was a diversion to draw out the ''Métis'' and at the same time, the Field Force under Middleton arrived at Batchoe.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=104}} Seeing his troops beginning to panic again, Middleton ordered his wagons to be drawn into a circle to form a strong defensive position.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|pages=104-105}} On 11 May 1885, Middleton observed that the outnumbered ''Métis'' and Cree had to rush from position to position on the Prairies and on the morning of 12 May 1885, Middleton ordered his artillery would open fire on his opponents to pin them down while his infantry would advance.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=105}} Nothing had happened as infantry claimed not to hear the fire of the artillery; after accusing his men of cowardice, Middleton attacked again on the afternoon and with a battalion commanded by a Conservative MP, Colonel Arthur Williams leading the attack.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=105}} Inspired by the example of Williams's battalion, other battalions began to charge forward. Shouting enthusiastically, the Canadians raced down from the hill, and disheartened ''Métis'' and Cree were soon defeated.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=105}} Morton described Middleton as cautious, but highly professional officer who was a better tactician than Dumont, who brought the war to a swift conclusion in a manner that was much less bloodier than it could have been.{{sfnp|Morton|1999|page=106}} For his service in the war, Middleton was [[knight]]ed by [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]] in 1885. He also received the thanks of the [[Parliament of Canada]] and the sum of $20,000. He resigned as head of the Militia in 1890 when a select committee of the [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]] criticized him for the misappropriation of furs from a Métis prisoner, Charles Bremner, during the rebellion. There were also other criticisms of Middleton's command during the Rebellion, such as his hesitancy to unleash the Canadian militia troops to assault the Metis positions at Batoche, and unfair treatmant and poor maintenance accorded the troops under his command. ==Family== [[File:Lady Middleton by William James Topley.jpg|left|thumb|Lady Marie Cecile Eugenie Middleton]] Frederick Dobson Middleton married, as his first wife, Mary Emily Hassall. He married in February 1870 as his second wife, Marie Cecile Eugénie Doucet, daughter of Theodore Doucet, N.P., of Montreal. She was born in Montreal in 1846, and was educated at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Sault-au-Recollet. The couple had two sons and a daughter. She died at Tateley, Hants, England, 1 November 1899.{{cite book |editor-last=Morgan |editor-first=Henry James |editor-link=Henry James Morgan |title=Types of Canadian Women and of Women who are or have been Connected with Canada |location=Toronto |publisher=Williams Briggs |date=1903 |url=https://archive.org/details/typesofcanadianw01morguoft/page/234 |page=234}} {{clear left}} == References == {{reflist}} == Bibliography == * {{cite book|ref=harv|last=Morton|first=Desmond|title=A Military History of Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ui8ecMckv08C&pg=PP1|year=1999|publisher=McClelland & Stewart|isbn=978-0-7710-6514-9}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box|title=[[Commander of the Canadian Army|General Officer Commanding the Militia of Canada]]|before=[[Richard Luard]]|after=[[Ivor Herbert, 1st Baron Treowen|Lord Treowen]]|years=1884–1890}} {{s-end}} {{Commander of the Canadian Army}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Middleton, Frederick Dobson}} [[Category:1825 births]] [[Category:1898 deaths]] [[Category:People from Belfast]] [[Category:British Army generals]] [[Category:Canadian generals]] [[Category:British military personnel of the Indian Rebellion of 1857]] [[Category:British military personnel of the New Zealand Wars]] [[Category:Commandants of Sandhurst]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Graduates of the Royal Military College, Sandhurst]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] [[Category:People of the North-West Rebellion]] [[Category:58th Regiment of Foot officers]] [[Category:96th Regiment of Foot officers]] [[Category:Worcestershire Regiment officers]] [[Category:People educated at Maidstone Grammar School]] [[Category:Masters of the Jewel Office]]

page.title: Frederick Francis IV, Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox royalty |name =Friedrich Franz IV |succession =[[Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin]] |image =Frederick Francis IV, Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin.jpg |reign =10 April 1897 – {{nowrap|14 November 1918}} |predecessor =[[Frederick Francis III, Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Frederick Francis III]] |spouse ={{marriage|[[Princess Alexandra of Hanover and Cumberland|Alexandra of Hanover and Cumberland]]|7 June 1904}} |issue=[[Friedrich Franz, Hereditary Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Hereditary Grand Duke Friedrich Franz]]
[[Duke Christian Louis of Mecklenburg|Duke Christian Ludwig]]
Duchess Olga
Duchess Thyra
[[Duchess Anastasia of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Anastasia, Princess Friedrich Ferdinand of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg]] |house =[[House of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Mecklenburg-Schwerin]] |father =[[Frederick Francis III, Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Frederick Francis III]] |mother =[[Grand Duchess Anastasia Mikhailovna of Russia|Anastasia Mikhailovna of Russia]] |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1882|04|9}} |birth_place =[[Palermo]], [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Kingdom of Italy]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1945|11|17|1882|04|9}} |death_place =[[Flensburg]], [[Allied-occupied Germany|Germany]] | religion = [[Lutheranism]] |}} '''Frederick Francis IV''' (Friedrich Franz Michael; 9 April 1882 – 17 November 1945) was the last Grand Duke of [[Grand Duchy of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Mecklenburg]]-[[Schwerin]] and [[regent]] of [[Grand Duchy of Mecklenburg-Strelitz|Mecklenburg-Strelitz]]. He inherited the throne when he was fifteen years old in 1897 and was forced to renounce it in 1918. ==Biography== ===Early life=== He was born in [[Palermo]] the son of [[Friedrich Franz III, Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin]], and [[Grand Duchess Anastasia Mikhailovna of Russia]]. He succeeded his father as Grand Duke upon his death on 10 April 1897, but due to his minority the grand duchy was governed by his uncle [[Duke John Albert of Mecklenburg|Duke Johann Albrecht]] as [[regent]] until Friedrich Franz came of age on 9 April 1901.{{Cite news| title =Celebration in Schwerin| publisher =[[New York Times]]| date =10 April 1901| url =https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1901/04/10/118463717.pdf| accessdate = 2007-10-23 | format=PDF}} ===Marriage and issue=== On 7 June 1904, Frederick Francis married [[Princess Alexandra of Hanover (1882–1963)|Princess Alexandra of Hanover and Cumberland]] in [[Gmunden]]. She was the second eldest daughter of [[Ernest Augustus, Crown Prince of Hanover]], and his wife [[Princess Thyra of Denmark]], a daughter of [[Christian IX of Denmark]]. They had five children:[http://www.angelfire.com/realm/gotha/gotha/mecklenburg.html Online Gotha] *[[Friedrich Franz, Hereditary Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Hereditary Grand Duke Friedrich Franz]] (22 April 1910 – 31 July 2001) *[[Duke Christian Louis of Mecklenburg|Duke Christian Ludwig]] (29 September 1912 – 18 July 1996) married [[Princess Barbara of Prussia]], daughter of [[Prince Sigismund of Prussia (1896-1978)|Prince Sigismund of Prussia]] *Duchess Olga (1916–1917) *[[Duchess Thyra of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Duchess Thyra]] (18 June 1919 – 27 September 1981) *[[Duchess Anastasia of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Duchess Anastasia]] (11 November 1922 – 25 January 1979) married [[Prince Friedrich Ferdinand of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg]] ===Abdication=== Following the 1918 suicide of [[Adolphus Frederick VI, Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Strelitz|Grand Duke Adolphus Frederick VI of Mecklenburg-Strelitz]], Frederick Francis took up the regency of Strelitz. This happened because the heir presumptive [[Duke Charles Michael of Mecklenburg|Duke Charles Michael]] was serving in the Russian Army at the time and had indicated that he wished to renounce his succession rights. Friedrich Franz abdicated the grand ducal throne on 14 November 1918 following the [[German Empire]]'s defeat in [[World War I]]; the regency ended at the same time. After his abdication, he was initially not allowed to live in Mecklenburg and had to move to Denmark. A year later, he was permitted to return. He recovered some of his former properties and occupied some of his former homes. Frederick Francis died on 17 November 1945 in [[Flensburg]] after being arrested by No6 RAF Security section on 9 November 1945. He was succeeded as head of the grand ducal house by his son [[Friedrich Franz, Hereditary Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Hereditary Grand Duke Friedrich Franz]].[http://www.heraldica.org/topics/royalty/HGMecklenburg.htm House laws of Mecklenburg] However, his former states became part of [[East Germany]]. His widow and children were forced to move to the West. ==Honours== ;German decorations''[https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_IZp4dvZCa04C/page/n67 Grossherzoglich Mecklenburg-Schwerinscher Staatskalendar]'', 1908, p. 1 {{columns-list|colwidth=25em| * {{Flagicon image|Flagge Großherzogtümer Mecklenburg.svg}} [[Mecklenburg]]: ** [[Order of the Wendish Crown]], Joint Grand Master ** [[Order of the Griffon (Mecklenburg)|Order of the Griffon]], Joint Grand Master ** [[Military Merit Cross (Mecklenburg-Schwerin)|Military Merit Cross]], Grand Master * {{Flag|Baden}}: ** [[House Order of Fidelity]], Knight ** [[Order of the Zähringer Lion]], [[Order of Berthold the First|Berthold the First]] Special Class * {{flagcountry|Kingdom of Bavaria}}: [[Order of St. Hubert]], KnightJustus Perthes, ''Almanach de Gotha 1922'' (1922) [https://archive.org/details/almanachdegotha1922goth/page/64 page 64] * {{flagicon|Saxe-Coburg and Gotha}} {{flagicon|Saxe-Altenburg}} {{flagicon|Saxe-Meiningen}} [[Ernestine duchies]]: [[Saxe-Ernestine House Order]], Grand Cross * {{flagicon|Kingdom of Hanover}} [[House of Hanover|Hanoverian Royal Family]]: ** [[Order of St. George {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101222022855/http://tornai.com/rendtagok.htm|date=22 December 2010}} * {{flagcountry|Principality of Bulgaria}}: ** [[Order of St. Alexander]], Grand Cross ** [[Order of Saints Cyril and Methodius]], Grand Cross * {{flag|Denmark}}: ** [[Order of the Elephant]], Knight – 3 August 1897{{cite book|author=Jørgen Pedersen|title=Riddere af Elefantordenen, 1559–2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=glw-AQAAIAAJ|year=2009|publisher=Syddansk Universitetsforlag|language=da|isbn=978-87-7674-434-2|p=466}} ** [[Order of the Dannebrog]], Grand Commander * {{flag|Netherlands}}: ** [[Order of the Netherlands Lion]], Grand Cross ** 1901 Wedding Medal of [[Wilhelmina of the Netherlands|Queen Wilhelmina]] and [[Duke Henry of Mecklenburg-Schwerin]] * {{flag|Russian Empire}}: ** [[Order of St. Andrew|Order of St. Andrew the Apostle the First-Called]], Knight ** [[Order of St. Alexander Nevsky]], Knight ** [[Order of St. of Chakri]], Knight with Chain ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; '''Gregory Sol "Greg" Hyatt''' is an American political activist and a former attorney and politician. He was a candidate for [[Governor of Massachusetts]] in [[Massachusetts gubernatorial election, 1986|1986]], but dropped out of the race due to allegations of forging names on his nomination papers, having ties to organized crime, and erratic personal behavior.
==Early life and political involvement== Hyatt was born and raised in [[Methuen, Massachusetts]]. His father was a local doctor. In 1971 he graduated from [[Central Catholic High School (Lawrence, Massachusetts)|Central Catholic High School]] in [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]]. He was class valedictorian. Hyatt attended [[Yale University]], where he was a member of the [[Yale Debate Association]] and the floor leader of the [[Party of the Right (Yale)|Party of the Right]] in the [[Yale Political Union]]. In 1979 he graduated from [[Boston College Law School]] and began practicing law.<ref name="3 Years After the Fall">{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Frank|title=Greg Hyatt: 3 Years After the Fall in '86|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=November 25, 1989}}</ref><ref name="National Review" /><ref name="Once Somebody" />
==Proposition 2½== Hyatt served as executive director of Citizens for Limited Taxation from 1979 to 1980.<ref name="National Review" /> He was one of the architects of [[Proposition 2½]], a ballot measure that limits property tax increases by Massachusetts municipalities and traveled the state to drum up support for the measure.<ref name="National Review">{{cite news|last=Brookhiser|first=Richard|title=Can they dump the Duke?|newspaper=National Review|date=July 18, 1986}}</ref><ref name="The Newburyport Daily News" /> During the [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|Reagan administration]], Hyatt worked in the [[United States Department of Education|Department of Education]] and the [[Small Business Administration]].<ref name="National Review" />
==1984 congressional race== Hyatt's political career began in 1984 when he was a candidate for the [[Massachusetts's 5th congressional district|5th congressional district]]. He defeated [[Thomas P. Tierney]] for the Republican nomination and faced Democratic State Senator [[Chester G. Atkins]] in the general election.<ref name=ElectionStatistics>{{cite book |author= |coauthors= |title=Election Statistics; The Commonwealth of Massachusetts 1984 |year= |publisher= |quote= | url=https://archive.org/stream/massachusettsele1984mass#page/286/mode/2up |isbn= }}</ref> In a heavily Democratic district,<ref>{{cite news|title=Reagan's campaign strategy, tactics challenged|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oJwyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=E-kFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4894,1137215|accessdate=30 July 2011|newspaper=Lawrence Journal-World|date=November 5, 1984|author=Rowland Evans|author2=Robert Novak}}</ref> Hyatt was able to finish a close second to Atkins.<ref name=ElectionStatistics />
==Anti-seat belt law activism== In 1985, Hyatt, along with radio host [[Jerry Williams (radio)|Jerry Williams]], led the effort to gather signatures to place a measure to repeal Massachusetts' mandatory seat belt law on the 1986 ballot. The question made it to the ballot and would be passed by the voters.<ref name="3 Years After the Fall" />
==1986 gubernatorial election== On March 13, 1986, Hyatt became the first Republican to enter the gubernatorial race.<ref name=Mohl>{{cite news |author=Bruce Mohl |coauthors= |title=GOP'S Hyatt Announces Candidacy for Governor |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/660025411.html?dids=660025411:660025411&FMT=ABS |quote= |work=Boston Globe |date=March 14, 1986 |accessdate=2011-01-11 }}</ref>
Hyatt ran on a platform of limiting state taxes, bringing back the death penalty, providing state aid to private schools, and competency testing and merit pay for teachers. He opposed the state law that made wearing a seat belt mandatory, the use of roadblocks to crack down on drunken driving, [[Desegregation busing|busing]], and the use of public funds for abortions.<ref name="National Review" /><ref name=Mohl />
Shortly before the Republican convention in April 1986, Associated Builders and Contractors, a group of Massachusetts builders and contractors that had hired Hyatt as a consultant on a petition drive, announced that they had fired him for ineffectuality and erratic behavior, including staring off into space, heavy coffee drinking, talking on the phone when no one was on the other end, and twice appearing naked before a secretary in his office.<ref name="3 Years After the Fall" /><ref name="National Review" /><ref name="political grist mill" />
At the convention, Hyatt was challenged by former [[Department of Conservation and Recreation (Massachusetts)|Metropolitan District Commissioner]] [[Guy Carbone]], and state representative [[Royall H. Switzler]], who was [[Draft (politics)|drafted]] at the convention by anti-Hyatt Republicans.<ref name="Dabilis">{{cite news |author=Andrew J. Dabilis |coauthors= |title=Switzler Drive Put Together in 4 1/2 Hours |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/659860941.html?dids=659860941:659860941&FMT=ABS&FMTS |quote= |work=Boston Globe |date=April 13, 1986 |accessdate=2011-01-11 }}</ref> After a strong showing for Switzler on the first ballot (891 votes for Hyatt, 775 votes for Switzler, 258 votes for Carbone), some of Hyatt's major supporters, including [[Ray Shamie]] and [[Papa Gino's]] founder Michael Valerio, announced that they would not oppose Switzler's nomination.<ref name="Dabilis" /> On the second ballot, Switzler won the nomination with 975 votes to Hyatt's 876 and Carbone's 60. Despite losing the nomination, Hyatt chose to stay in the race and run against Switzler in the Republican primary.<ref name="Mohl Gears">{{cite news |author=Bruce Mohl |coauthors= |title=GOP'S Gears Set in Motion; Switzler Plots Strategy, Signals Hyatt Should Quit |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/659862791.html?dids=659862791:659862791&FMT=ABS&FMTS |quote= |work=Boston Globe |date=April 14, 1986 |accessdate=2011-01-11 }}</ref>
During the campaign, Hyatt and his aides were investigated by the [[Massachusetts Attorney General]]'s office on charges for forging names on his nomination papers. He was also recorded discussing politics and accepting a cash gift from New England mobster George Kattar on a [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] wiretap. Charges were not brought against him in either case.<ref name="3 Years After the Fall" /><ref name="political grist mill">{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Frank|title=Suit heads for court, political grist mill|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=July 19, 1993}}</ref>
In June, Switzler dropped out of the race after inaccuracies about his military record were revealed, leaving Hyatt the only Republican candidate for Governor.<ref>{{cite news |author=Bruce Mohl |coauthors= |title=ACCUSATIONS, TURMOIL SWIRL OVER SWITZLER |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/660069841.html?dids=660069841:660069841&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT |quote= |work=Boston Globe |date=June 5, 1986 |accessdate=2010-06-18 }}</ref>
On July 14, Hyatt dropped out of the race.<ref>{{cite news |author=Bruce Mohl |coauthors= |title=ADS DEPICT TAX CAP AS A HYATT PROPOSAL |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/659733481.html?dids=659733481:659733481&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT |quote= |work=Boston Globe |date=October 18, 1986 |accessdate=2010-06-18 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hey, gang! It's all over!|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ppwrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=D_wFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6404,4735927|accessdate=30 July 2011|newspaper=Nashua Telegraph|date=July 17, 1986}}</ref> Despite dropping out, Hyatt won the Republican primary. He declined the nomination and write-in candidate [[George Kariotis]] was declared the nominee. Hyatt later stated he declined the nomination because Valerio and former Governor [[John A. Volpe]] promised to retire his campaign debts in exchange for not accepting the party's nomination, which they never followed up on. Ann Kramer, a Republican State Committee member who was at the meeting with Hyatt, Valerio, Volpe, and other party leaders stated that they agreed to help Hyatt raise money to help him repay his debt, but did not promise to retire it entirely.<ref name="3 Years After the Fall" />
==Later life== In November 1989, Hyatt gave his first interview after dropping out of the election. Hyatt described himself as still being in a "state of emotional shock" and feeling "gypped and violated". At the time of the interview he had been unable to find work for several months, was living off of a stipend provided to him by his father, going through a divorce, and undergoing psychological counseling. Since the election, Hyatt had gained 35 pounds and grew a mustache.<ref name="3 Years After the Fall" />
That same year, Hyatt sued Associated Builders and Contractors and its former executive Stephen Tocco for slander. During the suit it was revealed that Hyatt's psychiatrist had described him as having [[narcissistic personality disorder]] and having been in "[[Hypomania|hypomanic stages]]." Most of his defamation suit was dismissed, however the court allowed Hyatt's charge that Associated Builders had defamed him by claiming he had been fired stand (Hyatt contended that he was not fired, but quit). In September 1993, the case was settled out of court.<ref>{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Frank|title=Hyatt settles suit against Tocco|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=September 25, 1993}}</ref>
In 1992, Hyatt changed his voter registration to [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] so he could vote for [[Paul Tsongas]] in the [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 1992|Democratic presidential primary]]. He also voted for [[Marty Meehan]] in that year's [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1992|United States House of Representatives election]]. While he described himself as "still basically a conservative" he also stated that he "believe[d] societies should be judged by how they treat their less fortunate".<ref name="comeback kid">{{cite news|last=Turner|first=Robert L.|title=In Methuen, a comeback kid is running for mayor|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=June 1, 1993}}</ref>
In 1992, Hyatt was elected to the Methuen Charter Commission.<ref name="comeback kid" /> In 1993 and 2003, he was an unsuccessful candidate for Mayor of Methuen.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hyatt, Gregory S. "Greg"|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=30777|work=Our Campaigns|accessdate=30 July 2011}}</ref>
Hyatt ran a website, thebulldogedition.com, where he wrote about politics in Massachusetts and Methuen. The site was described by ''[[The Boston Globe|Boston Globe]]'' columnist [[Alex Beam]] as "belligerent" and "off-the-wall". A portion of the website had to be taken down due to a judge's order. As he did not have a computer, Hyatt updated the site from the [[Nevins Memorial Library]] in Methuen. In a 2005 Boston Globe column, Hyatt was described as occasionally working as a political or media consultant, on probation for making hostile threats, not having a car or computer, being in poor health, and described his living situation by stating "I bounce around". Hyatt said that he saw himself as a good candidate to host a talk show. He also stated that he rekindled his religious faith.<ref name="Once Somebody">{{cite news|last=Beam|first=Alex|title=He was Once Somebody, but who?|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=January 25, 2004}}</ref>
He later moved to [[Amesbury, Massachusetts]]. In 2007, he was a leader in the effort to get Proposition 1, a proposed initiative petition that would which would cap increases in property tax levies to 1% a year and eliminate the auto excise tax, on the ballot. On September 26, 2007 he was disbarred by the Board of Bar Overseers for "serious crimes", including intimidation of a witness and violating a protective order. Hyatt maintained his innocence and stated that he had only pleaded guilty because he did not have enough money to fight the charges in court. He had not practiced law since 2000, when he stopped paying his bar association dues.<ref name="The Newburyport Daily News">{{cite news|last=Tait|first=Stephen|title=Hyatt disbarred, still vows to push forward with Prop. 1|url=http://www.newburyportnews.com/local/x845826575/Hyatt-disbarred-still-vows-to-push-forward-with-Prop-1|accessdate=April 16, 2014|newspaper=The Newburyport Daily News|date=October 5, 2007}}</ref>

'''Hani Al-Dhabit Faraj Bait Al-Noobi''' ({{lang-ar|هاني الضابط فرج بيت النوبي}}; born 15 October 1979), commonly known as '''Hani Al-Dhabit''', is an [[Oman]]i [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Dhofar S.C.S.C.]] in [[Oman Professional League]].<ref>{{NFT player|id=4967|accessdate=}}</ref>
==Club career== Hani Al-Dhabit is a long-time veteran of the most successful sports club in Oman, [[Dhofar S.C.S.C.]] and has been in the squad for over 10 years. He is the captain of Dhofar and wears the number 14 jersey, as he had previously worn throughout his career with the national team.
He has also played for various clubs in GCC like for [[Baniyas SC]] of the [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Al Sadd SC]] of [[Qatar]] and [[Al Jahra SC]] of [[Kuwait]].
===Club career statistics=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !rowspan="2"|Club !rowspan="2"|Season !rowspan="2"|Division !colspan="2"|League !colspan="2"|Cup !colspan="2"|Continental<ref group=lower-alpha>Includes appearances in the [[AFC Cup]]</ref> !colspan="2"|Other<ref group=lower-alpha>Includes goals in the [[GCC Champions League]] and the [[Al-Karamah SC International Championship]]</ref> !colspan="2"|Total |- !Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan="2"|[[Dhofar S.C.S.C.|Dhofar]] |[[2003–04 Omani League|2003–04]] |rowspan="1"|[[Omani League]] ||-||2||-||2||0||0||-||0||-||4 |- !colspan="2"|Total !-!!2!!-!!2!!0!!0!!-!!0!!-!!4 |- |rowspan="2"|[[Al Jahra SC|Al-Jahra]] |[[Kuwaiti Premier League 2004–05|2004–05]] |rowspan="1"|[[Kuwaiti Premier League]] ||-||2||-||0||0||0||-||0||-||2 |- !colspan="2"|Total !-!!2!!-!!0!!0!!0!!-!!0!!-!!2 |- |rowspan="10"|[[Dhofar S.C.S.C.|Dhofar]] |[[2004–05 Omani League|2004–05]] |rowspan="9"|[[Oman Professional League|Oman Elite League]] ||-||1||-||3||0||0||-||0||-||4 |- |[[2005–06 Omani League|2005–06]] ||-||2||-||1||0||0||-||0||-||3 |- |[[2006–07 Omani League|2006–07]] ||-||6||-||0||-||1||-||0||-||7 |- |[[2007–08 Omani League|2007–08]] ||-||8||-||1||0||0||-||4||-||12 |- |[[2008–09 Omani League|2008–09]] ||-||7||-||0||0||0||-||0||-||7 |- |[[2009–10 Oman Mobile League|2009–10]] ||-||7||-||0||0||0||-||0||-||7 |- |[[2010–11 Oman Mobile League|2010–11]] ||-||1||-||3||0||0||-||1||-||5 |- |[[2011–12 Oman Elite League|2011–12]] ||-||3||-||5||0||0||-||0||-||8 |- |[[2012–13 Oman Elite League|2012–13]] ||-||2||-||0||5||1||-||0||-||3 |- !colspan="2"|Total !-!!37!!-!!13!!-!!2!!-!!5!!-!!55 |- !colspan="3"|Career total !-!!41!!-!!15!!-!!2!!-!!5!!-!!63 |} {{Reflist|group=lower-alpha}}
==International career== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:DhabitHaniGulfCup.png|thumb|left|200px|Hani Al-Dhabit, [[Oman]]i footballer]] --> He played for the [[Oman national football team]] from 1998 to 2008 and was the captain of the team in 2002 and 2003. His most successful season for the national team was during 2001-02 and he was the world's leading goalscorer in international matches in 2001.<ref name="rsssf.com">http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/iffhs-scor.html</ref>
===Arabian Gulf Cup=== Hani has made appearances in the [[14th Arabian Gulf Cup]], the [[15th Arabian Gulf Cup]], the [[16th Arabian Gulf Cup]] and the [[17th Arabian Gulf Cup]].
In the [[14th Arabian Gulf Cup]] in 1998, despite his young age, he scored a goal in a 2-2 draw against [[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]]. In the tournament, Oman finished at the fourth place with four points from one win and one draw.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?c=162&stage=1 | title= Gulf Cup14 - Bahrain 1998 | publisher= goalzz.com}}</ref>
He first showed his talent during the [[15th Arabian Gulf Cup]] in 2002 scoring five goals, a hat-trick in a 3-1 win over the then powerhouse 9-time competition winners, [[Kuwait national football team|Kuwait]], a goal in a 1-2 loss against [[Qatar national football team|Qatar]] and another in a 1-1 draw against [[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]]. At the end of the competition he was awarded with the "Top Goal Scorer" award.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?c=160&scorers=true | title= Gulf Cup15 - Saudi 2002 (Goal Scorers) | publisher= goalzz.com}}</ref> In the tournament, Oman finished at the fifth place with four points from one win and one draw.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?c=160 | title= Gulf Cup15 - Saudi 2002 | publisher= goalzz.com}}</ref>
Although not being successful in scoring any goals in both the [[16th Arabian Gulf Cup]] and the [[17th Arabian Gulf Cup]], he still made many appearances, and was handed the captain's band once again in the [[16th Arabian Gulf Cup]] in 2003–04.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?c=29&stage=1&sch=true | title= Gulf Cup16 - Kuwait 2003 | publisher= goalzz.com}}</ref> This time Hani led Oman to its most successful position ever yet in the [[Arabian Gulf Cup]] competition, reaching the final four round for the first time with eight points from two wins and two draws.
During the [[17th Arabian Gulf Cup]] in 2004, he was not assigned captaincy by [[Czechs|Czech]] coach, [[Milan Macala]]. He was featured widely as a substitute, but still received an adequate amount of playing time, and scored a goal in the penalty-kick shootout during the final in which Oman lost to the hosts [[Qatar]] in a penalty shootout after the goalkeeping sensation [[Ali Al-Habsi]] missed a penalty. [[Qatar national football team|Qatar]] won the match 6-5 on penalties after the match had ended 1-1 at normal time. [[Amad Al-Hosni]] was awarded the "Top Goal Scorer" award of the competition with a total of four goals.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?c=737 | title= 17th Gulf Cup - Qatar 2004 | publisher= goalzz.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?c=737&scorers=true | title= 17th Gulf Cup - Qatar 2004 (Goal Scorers) | publisher= goalzz.com}}</ref>
===AFC Asian Cup Qualification=== He scored five goals in the qualification for the [[2004 AFC Asian Cup]],<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/international/asia/asian-cup-qualification/2004-china/qualifying/r1761/ | title= ASIAN CUP QUALIFICATION 2004 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> one in a 7-0 win over [[Nepal national football team|Nepal]],<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2003/09/25/asia/asian-cup-qualification/nepal/oman/255515/?ICID=PL_MS_02 | title= NEPAL VS. OMAN 0 - 7 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> a brace in a 6-0 win over [[Vietnam national football team|Vietnam]],<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2003/09/29/asia/asian-cup-qualification/oman/vietnam/255519/?ICID=PL_MS_04 | title= OMAN VS. VIETNAM 6 - 0 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> other in a 3-1 win over [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]]<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2003/10/21/asia/asian-cup-qualification/oman/korea-republic/255524/?ICID=PL_MS_07 | title= OMAN VS. KOREA REPUBLIC 3 - 1 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> and another in a 2-0 win over [[Vietnam national football team|Vietnam]]<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2003/10/24/asia/asian-cup-qualification/oman/vietnam/255526/?ICID=PL_MS_09 | title= OMAN VS. VIETNAM 2 - 0 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> hence helping his team to qualify for the [[2004 AFC Asian Cup]]. In the tournament, Oman won four points in a 2-0 win over [[Thailand national football team|Thailand]]<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2004/07/28/asia/asian-cup/oman/thailand/255573/?ICID=PL_MS_10 | title= OMAN VS. THAILAND 2 - 0 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> and a 2-2 draw against [[Iran national football team|Iran]]<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2004/07/24/asia/asian-cup/oman/iran/255571/?ICID=PL_MS_01 | title= OMAN VS. IRAN 2 - 2 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> and hence failed to qualify for the quarter-finals.<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/international/asia/asian-cup/2004-china/group-stage/r1762/ | title= ASIAN CUP 2004 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref>
===FIFA World Cup Qualification=== He has made fourteen appearances in [[2002 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)|2002 FIFA World Cup qualification]] and has represented the national team in [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)|2010 FIFA World Cup qualification]].
He scored eleven goals in [[2002 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)|2002 FIFA World Cup qualification]],<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2007/10/08/asia/wc-qualifying-asia/oman/nepal/501076/ | title= OMAN VS. NEPAL 2 - 0 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> five goals in a 12-0 win over [[Laos national football team|Laos]],<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2001/04/30/asia/wc-qualifying-asia/oman/laos/1400120/?ICID=PL_MS_01 | title= OMAN VS. LAOS 12 - 0 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> a brace in the return leg in a 7-0 win over [[Laos national football team|Laos]],<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2001/05/04/asia/wc-qualifying-asia/laos/oman/1400122/?ICID=PL_MS_06 | title= LAOS VS. OMAN 0 - 7 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> a brace in a 7-0 win over [[Philippines national football team|Philippines]]<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2001/05/07/asia/wc-qualifying-asia/oman/philippines/1400124/?ICID=PL_MS_04 | title= OMAN VS. PHILIPPINES 7 - 0 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> and another in a 2-2 draw against the [[United Arab Emirates national football team|United Arab Emirates]].<ref>{{cite web | url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2001/10/19/asia/wc-qualifying-asia/united-arab-emirates/oman/1400275/ | title= UAE VS. OMAN 2 - 2 | publisher= soccerway.com}}</ref> During the qualifications, Oman had scored some of the most goals in the shortest period of time, with the largest margin wins in the team's history. Many of the goals were scored by Hani.
After eventually being knocked out of qualification, Hani had scored a total of 11 goals in 4 matches out of the 12 matches Oman had played. In one match, he was on the brink of a double [[hat-trick (football)|hat-trick]] but unfortunately he couldn't. At the end of the year, he was awarded the 2001 Top Goal Scorer Award with a total of 22 international goals,<ref>http://www.iffhs.de/?388d85ff0e003c4f05e91a55685fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70aeedb8a710 IFFHS 2001 World's Top Goal Scorer</ref> beating [[Spain national football team|Spain]]'s [[Raúl González|Raúl]], [[England national football team|England]]'s [[Michael Owen]], and [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]]'s [[Luís Figo]], becoming the first [[Oman]]i and only third [[Arab]], to win the title.
